p: During the SARS outbreak in 2003, wastewater aerosols were identified as a ‘highly probable’ transmission route affecting residents at the Amoy Gardens complex in Hong Kong. The outbreak at that location involved over 300 cases and 42 deaths [ 27]. Follow up investigations confirmed that high concentrations of viral aerosols in building sewer plumbing were drawn into apartment bathrooms through malfunctioning floor drains when bathroom exhaust fans were running [ 28]. Virus-laden aerosols originating in the bathroom were subsequently extracted via over-sized bathroom exhaust fans into the building’s light well and then spread under prevailing winds to adjacent units up to some 200 m away [ 29]. Immediately after the investigation, the management committee of the Amoy Gardens complex repaired all defects in the building’s plumbing system [ 28].
